questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
questions.solution:
Mucicarmine stain is used in the identification of cryptococcus.

Mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding Cryptococcus neoformans?

choices.text: It most commonly causes meningitis in AIDS patients
There are 3 serological types based on capsular polysaccharide
Niger seed agar is used to demonstrate melanin production

questions.solution:
Pathogenic varieties of cryptococcus including C. neoformans and C. gattii are laccase positive. They also have ability to grow at 37° C and these factors are used to differentiate them from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsular polysaccharide:

  • Three serotypes fall under Cryptococcus neoformans - A(var. grubii), D(var. neoformans), and AD(a hybrid of serotypes A and D). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished.
  • The serotypes B and C are now considered a different species - Cryptococcus gattii.

Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation of Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. C. neoformans and C. gattii produces brown colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin. Melanin is produced by laccase using caffeic acid as the substrate.

The following image shows pigmented colonies of C. gattii growing on niger seed agar.

Cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is an opportunistic infection seen in individuals with AIDS. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms cannot be grown on any culture media?
  1. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  2. Rhinosporidium seeberi 
  3. Histoplasma capsulatum
  4. Pneumocystis jirovecii
  5. Rhizopus oryzae
questions.solution:
Rhinosporidium seeberi and Pneumocystis jirovecii are non-cultivable organisms and cannot be grown on any culture media.

Another example of a non-cultivable fungus is Lacazia loboi. It causes Jorge Lobo's disease which is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis.

Rhizopus oryzae is a mold which is easily cultivable on SDA. Dimorphic fungi like Histoplasma capsulatum and Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis are identified based on their colony morphology on SDA.

Note: Recently, molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that Rhinosporidium is an aquatic protistan parasite. Infections due to Rhinosporidium have been classified under infections due to Protozoa under the ICD 11.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The findings of microscopic examination of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. Which is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the GMS stained smear showing the black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Chest X-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or with diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients having AIDS.

The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised patient presents with complaints of pain during swallowing. She describes it as a burning sensation that radiates to her back every time she swallows. Oral examination reveals creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of odynophagia, creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding yeasts with pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by Candida albicans. 

It is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised states like AIDS, diabetes etc.

Treatment includes topical azoles or nystatin.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of ________
questions.solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. 

Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in:

1. Invasive aspergillosis
2. Systemic candidiasis
3. Mucormycosis
4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses caused by Aspergillus species.

Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children. This test is especially useful in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or patients with hematologic malignancies. 

Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain.
questions.solution:
The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45o) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains.

The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the microscopic appearance is suggestive of fungal rhinosinusitis. The most probable causative organism is Aspergillus fumigatus. It is commonly involved in paranasal sinus mycoses (fungal sinusitis).

The disease has been described to have four types:

  • allergic
  • non-invasive
  • invasive
  • fulminant 

A possible fifth type called non-invasive destructive type may also exist.

Zygomycetes like mucor and rhizopus are the common agents in fulminant type of fungal sinusitis.

The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus:

  • The vesicle is conical.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus appears as follows:

  • The vesicle is globular.
  • Phialides are arranged in one or two rows.
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger appear as follows:

  • The vesicle is globular shaped.
  • Phialides are in two rows.
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum appear as follows:

  • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores(brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.  It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
questions.solution:
The β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usually diagnosed based on clinical features and culture.

The test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi. 

It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

Fungi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include

  • Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain (1-3)-β-d-glucan, and hence, the β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis ?
questions.solution:
Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

questions.text: A 68-year-old post-COVID-19 patient presented with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge and blurred vision. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass eroding the septum and hard palate was visualised. Lactophenol cotton blue mount from the culture is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Iron administration to patients with active infection should be avoided
Posaconazole can be used to treat it
Pulmonary form is the most common

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the LPCB mount showing aseptate hyphae branching at right-angles is strongly suggestive of mucormycosis. Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most common form.

Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the blood vessels. It can turn fatal on cerebral involvement and development of speticemia.

Risk factors for the infection include:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Elevated levels of free iron.
  • Defects in phagocytic function.
  • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.

Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug.
